cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
Apart from English, what is the official language of Canada?
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: 
Canada is a bilingual country with two official languages. While English is one of the official languages, the other is French. This bilingual status is rooted in the country's history, particularly due to the presence of French-speaking populations in regions like Quebec. The Canadian government recognizes both languages in federal institutions, and they are used in official documents, legislation, and government services.

Answer: French

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
Apart from English, what is the official language of Canada?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
["Since 1968, French has been one of Canada's two official languages. It is the sole official language of Quebec and one of the official languages of New Brunswick, Yukon, the Northwest Territories and Nunavut. The province of Ontario has no official languages defined in law, although the provincial government provides French language services in many parts of the province under the French Language Services Act.\n", "By the Official Languages Act in 1969, Canada recognized English and French as having equal status in the government of Canada. While French, with no specification as to dialect or variety, has the status of one of Canada's two official languages at the federal government level, English is the native language of the majority of Canadians. The federal government provides services and operates in both languages. French is the sole official language in Quebec at the provincial level and is co-official with English in New Brunswick. The provincial governments of Ontario, New Brunswick and Manitoba are required to provide services in French where justified by the number of francophones (those whose mother tongue is French or who use French on a daily basis). French is also an official language of all three territories. However, the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms requires all provinces and territories to provide primary and secondary education to their official-language minorities.\n", 'The official languages of Canada are English and French, which "have equality of status and equal rights and privileges as to their use in all institutions of the Parliament and Government of Canada," according to Canada\'s constitution. "Official bilingualism" is the term used in Canada to collectively describe the policies, constitutional provisions, and laws that ensure legal equality of English and French in the Parliament and courts of Canada, protect the linguistic rights of English and French-speaking minorities in different provinces, and ensure a level of government services in both languages across Canada.\n', "Although no Canadian province has officially adopted English as its sole official language, English is the de facto language of government services and internal government operations in Canada's seven remaining provinces. Service levels in French vary greatly from one province to another (and sometimes within different parts of the same province).\n", 'English and French are recognized by the Constitution of Canada as official languages. All federal government laws are thus enacted in both English and French, with government services available in both languages. Two of Canada\'s territories give official status to indigenous languages. In Nunavut, Inuktitut and Inuinnaqtun are official languages, alongside the national languages of English and French, and Inuktitut is a common vehicular language in territorial government. In the Northwest Territories, the "Official Languages Act" declares that there are eleven different languages: Chipewyan, Cree, English, French, Gwich\'in, Inuinnaqtun, Inuktitut, Inuvialuktun, North Slavey, South Slavey, and Tłįchǫ. Multicultural media are widely accessible across the country and offer specialty television channels, newspapers, and other publications in many minority languages.\n', '² Canada has two official languages, English and French.br\n', 'Under the heading "Official Languages of Canada", the section reads:\n', "A multitude of languages are used in Canada. According to the 2011 census, English and French are the mother tongues of 56.9% and 21.3% of Canadians respectively. In total 85.6% of Canadians have working knowledge of English while 30.1% have a working knowledge of French. Under the Official Languages Act of 1969, both English and French have official federal status throughout Canada, in respect of all government services, including the courts, and all federal legislation is enacted bilingually. New Brunswick is the only Canadian province that has both English and French as its official languages to the same extent, with constitutional entrenchment. Quebec's official language is French, although, in that province, the Constitution requires that all legislation be enacted in both French and English, and court proceedings may be conducted in either language. Similar constitutional protections are in place in Manitoba.\n", 'In 2011, the total number of native French speakers in Canada was around 7.3 million (22% of the entire population), while another 2 million spoke it as a second language. At the federal level, it has official status alongside English. At the provincial level, French is the sole official language of Quebec as well as one of two official languages of New Brunswick, and jointly official (derived from its federal legal status) in Nunavut, Yukon, and the Northwest Territories. Government services are offered in French at select localities in Manitoba and Ontario (through the French Language Services Act) and, to a lesser extent, elsewhere in the country, depending largely on the proximity to Quebec and/or French Canadian influence on any given region.\n', 'Languages of Canada\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To enhance the model's understanding of the question regarding Canada's official languages, we can extract and analyze several key pieces of information from the provided passages. These pieces of content may be less familiar or require deeper contextual understanding. 

### Extracted Content and Analysis

1. **Official Languages Act of 1969**:
   - **Content**: The Official Languages Act recognized English and French as having equal status in the government of Canada.
   - **Role**: This act is foundational in establishing the bilingual nature of Canadian governance. Understanding this act helps clarify the legal framework that supports the coexistence of English and French as official languages.

2. **Provincial Language Status**:
   - **Content**: French is the sole official language of Quebec and one of the official languages of New Brunswick, while English is the de facto language in most provinces.
   - **Role**: This distinction highlights the regional variations in language policy across Canada. It illustrates how language status can differ significantly from one province to another, which is crucial for understanding the sociolinguistic landscape of the country.

3. **Indigenous Languages**:
   - **Content**: In Nunavut, Inuktitut and Inuinnaqtun are official languages alongside English and French. The Northwest Territories recognizes eleven different languages, including several Indigenous languages.
   - **Role**: This information expands the model's understanding of Canada's linguistic diversity beyond just English and French. It emphasizes the importance of Indigenous languages and their recognition in official contexts, which is vital for a comprehensive view of Canada's language policies.

4. **Bilingualism in Government Services**:
   - **Content**: All federal government laws are enacted in both English and French, and services are available in both languages.
   - **Role**: This underscores the practical implications of official bilingualism, showing how it affects citizens' interactions with government institutions. It also highlights the commitment to providing equitable services to both language groups.

5. **Census Data on Language Use**:
   - **Content**: According to the 2011 census, 56.9% of Canadians speak English as their mother tongue, while 21.3% speak French.
   - **Role**: This statistical data provides insight into the demographic realities of language use in Canada. It helps contextualize the significance of English and French in the daily lives of Canadians and informs discussions about language policy and education.

6. **Constitutional Protections**:
   - **Content**: The Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms requires provinces and territories to provide education to official-language minorities.
   - **Role**: This legal requirement emphasizes the protection of linguistic rights and the importance of maintaining language diversity in education, which is critical for fostering bilingualism and supporting minority language communities.

### Conclusion

The extracted content serves to enrich the model's understanding of the complexities surrounding Canada's official languages. By incorporating legal, regional, demographic, and sociolinguistic perspectives, the model can better appreciate the nuances of language policy in Canada, which is essential for accurately answering questions related to the country's official languages. This comprehensive understanding can also aid in recognizing the broader implications of bilingualism and the role of Indigenous languages in the Canadian context.

This bilingual status is rooted in the country's history, particularly due to the presence of French-speaking populations in regions like Quebec. The Canadian government recognizes both languages in federal institutions, and they are used in official documents, legislation, and government services.

Answer: French

knowledge enhanced inference process:
Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

Canada is officially bilingual, recognizing both English and French as its official languages. This bilingual status is enshrined in the **Official Languages Act of 1969**, which established the equal status of both languages in federal institutions. This means that all federal government laws and services are provided in both languages, ensuring that citizens can interact with the government in their preferred language.

The presence of French-speaking populations, particularly in **Quebec**, where French is the sole official language, plays a significant role in this bilingual framework. Additionally, **New Brunswick** is unique as it is the only province where both English and French are constitutionally recognized as official languages. 

Beyond English and French, Canada is home to a rich tapestry of languages, including Indigenous languages. In **Nunavut**, for example, Inuktitut and Inuinnaqtun are recognized as official languages alongside English and French. The **Northwest Territories** recognizes eleven different languages, showcasing the country's linguistic diversity.

Demographically, according to the 2011 census, approximately **56.9%** of Canadians speak English as their mother tongue, while **21.3%** speak French. This data highlights the significant role both languages play in the daily lives of Canadians. Furthermore, the **Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms** mandates that provinces and territories provide education to official-language minorities, reinforcing the importance of maintaining language diversity and supporting bilingualism.

In summary, the recognition of both English and French as official languages, along with the acknowledgment of Indigenous languages, reflects Canada's commitment to linguistic diversity and the rights of its citizens.

### Answer:
French

Task Description:
Please extract foundational knowledge that may be familiar to the model or advanced information beyond the model's already familiar foundational knowledge from these passages, and analyze the role of these contents.
Summarize and consolidate these contents, which should deepen the model's understanding of the question through familiarity with these basic and advanced pieces of information. 
This process aims to encourage the model to comprehend the question more thoroughly and expand its knowledge boundaries.

To address the question of Canada's official languages, we can extract and analyze foundational and advanced information from the provided passages. 

### Foundational Knowledge:
1. **Official Languages**: Canada recognizes two official languages: English and French. This status is enshrined in the Constitution of Canada and is supported by the Official Languages Act of 1969.
2. **Bilingualism in Government**: Both languages have equal status in federal institutions, meaning that government services, laws, and court proceedings are available in both English and French.
3. **Provincial Variations**: French is the sole official language of Quebec and is co-official with English in New Brunswick. Other provinces, like Ontario, do not have an official language defined by law but provide services in French under specific acts.

### Advanced Information:
1. **Territorial Languages**: In addition to English and French, some territories recognize indigenous languages as official. For example, Nunavut recognizes Inuktitut and Inuinnaqtun, while the Northwest Territories recognizes eleven languages, including various indigenous languages alongside English and French.
2. **Demographics**: According to the 2011 census, a significant portion of Canadians speak English (56.9% as a mother tongue) and French (21.3% as a mother tongue). The working knowledge of both languages is also notable, with 85.6% of Canadians having some proficiency in English and 30.1% in French.
3. **Legislative Protections**: The Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms mandates that provinces and territories provide education and services to official-language minorities, ensuring that both English and French speakers have access to government services.

### Role of the Contents:
- **Understanding Language Policy**: The passages illustrate Canada's commitment to bilingualism and the protection of linguistic rights, which is crucial for understanding the cultural and political landscape of the country.
- **Cultural Diversity**: The recognition of indigenous languages alongside English and French highlights Canada's multicultural identity and the importance of linguistic diversity.
- **Regional Differences**: The varying levels of French language services across provinces and territories reflect the historical and demographic influences on language use in Canada.

### Summary:
In summary, Canada has two official languages: English and French, recognized at the federal level with equal status. French is the sole official language in Quebec and co-official in New Brunswick. Indigenous languages also hold official status in certain territories. The linguistic landscape is shaped by demographic factors, regional policies, and constitutional protections that ensure access to services for both English and French speakers. This understanding deepens the model's comprehension of Canada's language policies and cultural diversity, providing a more nuanced view of the question regarding official languages in Canada.

knowledge enhanced inference process:
Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To answer the question regarding Canada's official languages, we start with the foundational knowledge that Canada recognizes two official languages: English and French. This bilingual status is not only a reflection of the country's history but also a constitutional commitment, as outlined in the Official Languages Act of 1969. 

1. **Official Languages**: The Constitution of Canada explicitly recognizes English and French as official languages, ensuring their equal status in federal institutions. This means that all government services, legislation, and court proceedings are available in both languages.

2. **Provincial and Territorial Variations**: French is the sole official language of Quebec, reflecting the province's significant French-speaking population. In New Brunswick, both English and French are co-official languages, which is unique among the provinces. Other provinces, such as Ontario, do not have an official language defined by law but provide French language services in certain areas, demonstrating a commitment to bilingualism where justified by the local population.

3. **Indigenous Languages**: Beyond English and French, some territories recognize indigenous languages as official. For instance, Nunavut recognizes Inuktitut and Inuinnaqtun, while the Northwest Territories acknowledges eleven languages, including various indigenous languages alongside English and French. This highlights Canada's commitment to linguistic diversity and the importance of recognizing the rights of indigenous populations.

4. **Demographics and Language Proficiency**: According to the 2011 census, a significant portion of Canadians are bilingual, with 56.9% speaking English as their mother tongue and 21.3% speaking French. Furthermore, 85.6% of Canadians have some working knowledge of English, while 30.1% have a working knowledge of French. This demographic data underscores the practical implications of bilingualism in Canada.

5. **Legislative Protections**: The Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms mandates that provinces and territories provide education and services to official-language minorities. This ensures that both English and French speakers have equitable access to government services, reinforcing the principle of bilingualism at all levels of government.

### Summary:
In summary, Canada has two official languages: English and French, which are recognized at the federal level with equal status. French is the sole official language in Quebec and co-official in New Brunswick. Indigenous languages also hold official status in certain territories, reflecting Canada's multicultural identity. The linguistic landscape is shaped by demographic factors, regional policies, and constitutional protections that ensure access to services for both English and French speakers, as well as indigenous populations.

### Answer:
French

Task Description:
Please extract content from these passages that can help enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities.
consolidate these contents, and analyze how the selected information may impact the improvement of the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities.

To enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities, we can extract and consolidate key information from the provided passages regarding the official languages of Canada. Here’s a summary of the relevant content:

### Consolidated Information:

1. **Official Languages**: Canada recognizes two official languages at the federal level: English and French. This recognition is enshrined in the Constitution and the Official Languages Act of 1969, which grants both languages equal status in government institutions.

2. **Provincial Language Status**:
   - **Quebec**: French is the sole official language.
   - **New Brunswick**: Both English and French are co-official languages.
   - **Other Provinces**: Ontario, Manitoba, and others provide varying degrees of French language services but do not have official languages defined in law.
   - **Territories**: In addition to English and French, indigenous languages have official status in Nunavut and the Northwest Territories.

3. **Government Services**: Federal government services are available in both English and French, and all federal laws are enacted in both languages. The level of French services varies by province, influenced by the local francophone population.

4. **Census Data**: According to the 2011 census, a significant portion of the Canadian population speaks English (56.9%) and French (21.3%) as their mother tongues, with a notable percentage having working knowledge of both languages.

5. **Cultural and Linguistic Diversity**: Canada is home to a multitude of languages, reflecting its multicultural society. This diversity includes indigenous languages recognized in certain territories.

### Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:

1. **Understanding Relationships**: By recognizing the legal framework that establishes the status of languages in Canada, the model can better understand the causal relationships between language policy, demographic factors, and government services. For example, the presence of a significant francophone population in a province may lead to more robust French language services.

1. **Bilingual Framework**: Canada is officially bilingual, recognizing both English and French as its official languages at the federal level. 2. **Legal Recognition**: The Official Languages Act of 1969 and the Canadian Constitution ensure that both languages have equal status in government institutions. This means that all federal legislation and government services must be available in both languages, reflecting the country's commitment to bilingualism.

3. **Provincial Variations**:
   - **Quebec**: French is the sole official language, reflecting the province's majority francophone population. This status influences local governance, education, and public services.
   - **New Brunswick**: This province uniquely recognizes both English and French as co-official languages, ensuring equal access to services in both languages.
   - **Other Provinces**: Provinces like Ontario and Manitoba provide varying degrees of French language services but do not have official languages defined in law. The availability of these services often correlates with the size of the francophone population in those areas.
   - **Territories**: In Nunavut and the Northwest Territories, indigenous languages also hold official status alongside English and French, highlighting Canada's commitment to linguistic diversity.

4. **Demographic Insights**: According to the 2011 census, a significant portion of Canadians are bilingual, with 56.9% speaking English and 21.3% speaking French as their mother tongues. This demographic data can inform predictions about language use trends and the demand for government services in both languages.

5. **Cultural and Linguistic Diversity**: Canada’s multicultural society is reflected in its linguistic diversity, which includes numerous indigenous languages recognized in specific regions. This diversity necessitates a nuanced approach to language policy and service provision.

For instance, a higher concentration of French speakers in a province may lead to increased funding and resources for French language services.

cognition.content:
Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.
You are a scientist researching fact-checking and addressing model illusions in artificial intelligence. 
To answer the following question:
Apart from English, what is the official language of Canada?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
["Since 1968, French has been one of Canada's two official languages. It is the sole official language of Quebec and one of the official languages of New Brunswick, Yukon, the Northwest Territories and Nunavut. The province of Ontario has no official languages defined in law, although the provincial government provides French language services in many parts of the province under the French Language Services Act.\n", "By the Official Languages Act in 1969, Canada recognized English and French as having equal status in the government of Canada. While French, with no specification as to dialect or variety, has the status of one of Canada's two official languages at the federal government level, English is the native language of the majority of Canadians. The federal government provides services and operates in both languages. French is the sole official language in Quebec at the provincial level and is co-official with English in New Brunswick. The provincial governments of Ontario, New Brunswick and Manitoba are required to provide services in French where justified by the number of francophones (those whose mother tongue is French or who use French on a daily basis). French is also an official language of all three territories. However, the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms requires all provinces and territories to provide primary and secondary education to their official-language minorities.\n", 'The official languages of Canada are English and French, which "have equality of status and equal rights and privileges as to their use in all institutions of the Parliament and Government of Canada," according to Canada\'s constitution. "Official bilingualism" is the term used in Canada to collectively describe the policies, constitutional provisions, and laws that ensure legal equality of English and French in the Parliament and courts of Canada, protect the linguistic rights of English and French-speaking minorities in different provinces, and ensure a level of government services in both languages across Canada.\n', "Although no Canadian province has officially adopted English as its sole official language, English is the de facto language of government services and internal government operations in Canada's seven remaining provinces. Service levels in French vary greatly from one province to another (and sometimes within different parts of the same province).\n", 'English and French are recognized by the Constitution of Canada as official languages. All federal government laws are thus enacted in both English and French, with government services available in both languages. Two of Canada\'s territories give official status to indigenous languages. In Nunavut, Inuktitut and Inuinnaqtun are official languages, alongside the national languages of English and French, and Inuktitut is a common vehicular language in territorial government. In the Northwest Territories, the "Official Languages Act" declares that there are eleven different languages: Chipewyan, Cree, English, French, Gwich\'in, Inuinnaqtun, Inuktitut, Inuvialuktun, North Slavey, South Slavey, and Tłįchǫ. Multicultural media are widely accessible across the country and offer specialty television channels, newspapers, and other publications in many minority languages.\n', '² Canada has two official languages, English and French.br\n', 'Under the heading "Official Languages of Canada", the section reads:\n', "A multitude of languages are used in Canada. According to the 2011 census, English and French are the mother tongues of 56.9% and 21.3% of Canadians respectively. In total 85.6% of Canadians have working knowledge of English while 30.1% have a working knowledge of French. Under the Official Languages Act of 1969, both English and French have official federal status throughout Canada, in respect of all government services, including the courts, and all federal legislation is enacted bilingually. New Brunswick is the only Canadian province that has both English and French as its official languages to the same extent, with constitutional entrenchment. Quebec's official language is French, although, in that province, the Constitution requires that all legislation be enacted in both French and English, and court proceedings may be conducted in either language. Similar constitutional protections are in place in Manitoba.\n", 'In 2011, the total number of native French speakers in Canada was around 7.3 million (22% of the entire population), while another 2 million spoke it as a second language. At the federal level, it has official status alongside English. At the provincial level, French is the sole official language of Quebec as well as one of two official languages of New Brunswick, and jointly official (derived from its federal legal status) in Nunavut, Yukon, and the Northwest Territories. Government services are offered in French at select localities in Manitoba and Ontario (through the French Language Services Act) and, to a lesser extent, elsewhere in the country, depending largely on the proximity to Quebec and/or French Canadian influence on any given region.\n', 'Languages of Canada\n']

Canada is officially recognized as a bilingual country with two official languages: English and French. This bilingual status is enshrined in the Official Languages Act, which ensures that both languages have equal status in federal institutions. The presence of French-speaking populations, particularly in Quebec, has significantly influenced this linguistic landscape.

Additionally, French is recognized as an official language in the territories of Nunavut, Yukon, and the Northwest Territories. 3. **Indigenous Languages**: In Nunavut, Inuktitut and Inuinnaqtun are also recognized as official languages alongside English and French. The Northwest Territories recognize eleven official languages, including various Indigenous languages. This aspect broadens the understanding of Canada’s linguistic diversity beyond just English and French, emphasizing the importance of Indigenous languages in the country’s cultural fabric.

4. **Bilingualism and Government Services**: Federal government services are available in both English and French. The variability in service levels in French across provinces is also noteworthy, as it reflects the differing degrees of French-speaking populations and government support.

5. **Census Data**: According to the 2011 census, 56.9% of Canadians speak English as their mother tongue, while 21.3% speak French. This demographic data is crucial for understanding the linguistic distribution and the significance of both languages in Canadian society.

6. **Variability in Service Levels**: The differences in service levels in French across provinces highlight the practical challenges of implementing bilingualism in Canada. This variability should be considered when discussing the effectiveness of Canada’s bilingual policies.

question_info.question: Apart from English, what is the official language of Canada?
passages:
Since 1968, French has been one of Canada's two official languages. It is the sole official language of Quebec and one of the official languages of New Brunswick, Yukon, the Northwest Territories and Nunavut. The province of Ontario has no official languages defined in law, although the provincial government provides French language services in many parts of the province under the French Language Services Act.
By the Official Languages Act in 1969, Canada recognized English and French as having equal status in the government of Canada. While French, with no specification as to dialect or variety, has the status of one of Canada's two official languages at the federal government level, English is the native language of the majority of Canadians. The federal government provides services and operates in both languages. French is the sole official language in Quebec at the provincial level and is co-official with English in New Brunswick. The provincial governments of Ontario, New Brunswick and Manitoba are required to provide services in French where justified by the number of francophones (those whose mother tongue is French or who use French on a daily basis). French is also an official language of all three territories. However, the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms requires all provinces and territories to provide primary and secondary education to their official-language minorities.
The official languages of Canada are English and French, which "have equality of status and equal rights and privileges as to their use in all institutions of the Parliament and Government of Canada," according to Canada's constitution. "Official bilingualism" is the term used in Canada to collectively describe the policies, constitutional provisions, and laws that ensure legal equality of English and French in the Parliament and courts of Canada, protect the linguistic rights of English and French-speaking minorities in different provinces, and ensure a level of government services in both languages across Canada.
Although no Canadian province has officially adopted English as its sole official language, English is the de facto language of government services and internal government operations in Canada's seven remaining provinces. Service levels in French vary greatly from one province to another (and sometimes within different parts of the same province).
English and French are recognized by the Constitution of Canada as official languages. All federal government laws are thus enacted in both English and French, with government services available in both languages. Two of Canada's territories give official status to indigenous languages. In Nunavut, Inuktitut and Inuinnaqtun are official languages, alongside the national languages of English and French, and Inuktitut is a common vehicular language in territorial government. In the Northwest Territories, the "Official Languages Act" declares that there are eleven different languages: Chipewyan, Cree, English, French, Gwich'in, Inuinnaqtun, Inuktitut, Inuvialuktun, North Slavey, South Slavey, and Tłįchǫ. Multicultural media are widely accessible across the country and offer specialty television channels, newspapers, and other publications in many minority languages.
² Canada has two official languages, English and French.br
Under the heading "Official Languages of Canada", the section reads:
A multitude of languages are used in Canada. According to the 2011 census, English and French are the mother tongues of 56.9% and 21.3% of Canadians respectively. In total 85.6% of Canadians have working knowledge of English while 30.1% have a working knowledge of French. Under the Official Languages Act of 1969, both English and French have official federal status throughout Canada, in respect of all government services, including the courts, and all federal legislation is enacted bilingually. New Brunswick is the only Canadian province that has both English and French as its official languages to the same extent, with constitutional entrenchment. Quebec's official language is French, although, in that province, the Constitution requires that all legislation be enacted in both French and English, and court proceedings may be conducted in either language. Similar constitutional protections are in place in Manitoba.
In 2011, the total number of native French speakers in Canada was around 7.3 million (22% of the entire population), while another 2 million spoke it as a second language. At the federal level, it has official status alongside English. At the provincial level, French is the sole official language of Quebec as well as one of two official languages of New Brunswick, and jointly official (derived from its federal legal status) in Nunavut, Yukon, and the Northwest Territories. Government services are offered in French at select localities in Manitoba and Ontario (through the French Language Services Act) and, to a lesser extent, elsewhere in the country, depending largely on the proximity to Quebec and/or French Canadian influence on any given region.
Languages of Canada
